issue.title: Web-based visualization dashboard for music organization database

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
# Web Visualization Dashboard

## Overview
Create an interactive web dashboard to visualize the music organization database created by ordr.fm.

## Motivation
With the comprehensive metadata database now tracking all operations (#20), we need a way to:
- Visualize collection statistics
- Browse organization structure
- Track processing history
- Enable undo/recovery operations
- Explore artist relationships and aliases

## Proposed Features

### Core Visualizations
- [ ] Collection overview (albums, tracks, artists, labels)
- [ ] Quality distribution pie chart
- [ ] Organization mode breakdown
- [ ] Timeline of processing activities

### Interactive Elements
- [ ] Artist alias network graph
- [ ] Label rankings and statistics
- [ ] Searchable album/track browser
- [ ] Move history with undo capability

### Advanced Features
- [ ] Sunburst chart for hierarchical exploration
- [ ] Real-time updates during processing
- [ ] Export reports as PDF
- [ ] Dark mode support

## Technical Stack
- Node.js/Express backend
- SQLite database connection
- D3.js/Chart.js for visualizations
- Responsive design for mobile

## Starting Point
Basic package.json and README already created in `/visualization` directory during #20 implementation.

## Benefits
- Better understanding of collection organization
- Easy identification of organization issues
- Visual exploration of artist relationships
- Simple undo/recovery interface
- Export statistics for sharing

## API Endpoints:
- `GET /api/stats` - Overall collection statistics
- `GET /api/albums` - Album listing with filters
- `GET /api/artists` - Artist data including aliases
- `GET /api/labels` - Label statistics and rankings
- `GET /api/timeline` - Processing history over time
- `GET /api/moves` - Move history for undo functionality

```bash
cd visualization
npm install
npm test  # Uses test database
# OR with real database:
ORDRFM_DB=/path/to/ordr.fm.metadata.db npm start
```

## Next Steps:
- Add real-time updates during processing
- Implement batch undo operations
- Add drag-and-drop reorganization
- Create mobile-responsive design
- Add dark mode toggle

The visualization is ready for testing\! Open http://localhost:3000 after starting the server.

pull_request.body:
# Advanced Electronic Music Organization

## Summary
Implements comprehensive electronic music organization with intelligent routing, artist alias resolution, and metadata tracking.

## Features Implemented

### ðŸŽ¯ Core Electronic Organization
- **Intelligent organization modes**: artist, label, series, remix, underground, hybrid
- **Smart routing logic**: Compares artist vs label release counts
- **Compilation detection**: VA releases and series grouping
- **Remix hierarchies**: Automatic remix artist extraction
- **Vinyl side markers**: A1, B2 from Discogs data
- **Underground handling**: White labels and promos

### ðŸ”„ Artist Alias Resolution
- Groups aliases under primary name (Uwe Schmidt case study)
- Counts releases across all aliases
- Configurable alias groups
- Smart fallback logic

### ðŸ“Š Metadata Database
- Comprehensive SQLite tracking
- All operations recorded for undo/recovery
- JSON export for visualization
- Node.js visualization starter included

### ðŸ§  Hybrid Intelligence
- Automatically selects best organization mode
- Priority: Series > Underground > Remix > Label > Artist
- Falls back intelligently based on collection

## Technical Changes
- 500+ lines of organization logic
- 25 new functions (15 electronic + 4 alias + 6 database)
- 18 configuration options
- 8 new CLI arguments
- 6 database tables for tracking

## Testing
âœ… Syntax validation passed
âœ… Dry-run mode tested
âœ… Help output verified
âœ… All functions implemented

## Usage Example
```bash
# Enable all electronic features
./ordr.fm.sh --enable-electronic --discogs \
  --alias-groups "Uwe Schmidt,Atom TM,Senor Coconut" \
  --group-aliases --move
```

## Related Issues
- Closes #20 (Advanced electronic music organization)
- Closes #19 (Discogs API integration) - already closed
- Enables #23 (Visualization dashboard) - created
- Enables #24 (Automated alias detection) - created

## Next Steps
1. Merge to main
2. Test with real electronic collections
3. Implement visualization dashboard (#23)
4. Add automated alias detection (#24)

issue.title: Automated artist alias detection using fuzzy matching

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
# Automated Artist Alias Detection

## Overview
Implement fuzzy matching and heuristics to automatically detect artist aliases without manual configuration.

## Problem
Artists like Uwe Schmidt have 30+ aliases. Currently requires manual configuration of alias groups. We should detect these automatically.

## Proposed Solution

### Detection Methods
1. **Fuzzy Name Matching**
   - Levenshtein distance for similar names
   - Soundex/Metaphone for phonetic matching
   - N-gram similarity scoring

2. **Metadata Correlation**
   - Same label patterns across names
   - Similar catalog number formats
   - Overlapping collaboration patterns
   - Release date clustering

3. **Discogs/MusicBrainz Data**
   - Query for known aliases
   - Cross-reference artist IDs
   - Build alias database over time

### Implementation Ideas
```bash
detect_potential_aliases() {
    local artist="$1"
    # Check for common patterns:
    # - "Artist aka Other Name"
    # - Similar names in same label
    # - Featuring patterns
    # - Remix relationships
}
```

### Benefits
- Zero configuration for most users
- Discovers aliases automatically
- Learns from your collection
- Improves over time

### Challenges
- False positive prevention
- Performance with large collections
- Handling edge cases

## Related
- Builds on #20 alias infrastructure
- Could integrate with #21 MusicBrainz
- Enhances smart organization

labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
## Problem
Electronic music has unique organizational needs that standard album-based organization doesn't handle well:
- Label series (Kompakt Pop Ambient, Fabric mix series, Essential Mix compilations)
- Complex remix structures with multiple artists per track
- 12" singles with A/B side organization
- Compilation albums with individual track organization needs
- Underground label catalog numbering systems

## Solution
Implement electronic music specific organization patterns that:
- Recognize and organize label series systematically
- Handle remix artist attribution and organization
- Support vinyl-style A/B side organization for 12" singles
- Provide compilation track organization options
- Support underground label catalog patterns

## Electronic Music Features
### **Label Series Organization**
- Automatic series detection (e.g., "KOMPAKT 001", "FABRIC 150", "GOTT 001")
- Series-based organization: `Label Series/[SeriesNum] Artist - Title`
- Configurable series patterns for different label styles
- Series completion tracking and gap identification

### **Remix and Collaboration Handling**
- Intelligent remix artist extraction: "Artist - Track (Remixer Remix)"
- Multi-artist compilation organization
- Featured artist standardization
- Producer vs remixer vs vocalist distinction

### **Vinyl 12" Organization**
- A/B side detection and organization
- Track position preservation (A1, A2, B1, B2)
- Extended mix vs radio edit handling
- Multi-format organization (12", digital, CD)

### **Underground Label Support**
- Flexible catalog numbering patterns
- White label and promo handling
- Bootleg and unofficial release identification
- Limited edition and special release tagging

## Organization Examples
```
# Label Series Mode
Lossless/
â”œâ”€â”€ Kompakt Pop Ambient/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ [KOMPAKT 001] GAS - Pop/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ [KOMPAKT 002] Triola - Triola/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [KOMPAKT 003] Various - Pop Ambient 2001/
â”œâ”€â”€ Fabric Series/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ [FABRIC 01] Craig Richards - Fabric 01/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [FABRIC 02] Jeff Mills - Fabric 02/

# Remix Organization Mode  
Lossless/
â”œâ”€â”€ Underground Resistance/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Electronic Warfare (1990)/
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 01 - Predator (Original Mix).flac
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 02 - Predator (Underground Resistance Remix).flac
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ 03 - Predator (Jeff Mills Remix).flac
```

## Configuration Options
- `--electronic-mode` to enable electronic music specific organization
- `--label-series` to organize by label series when detected
- `--remix-handling <style>` (preserve, extract, organize-by-remixer)
- `--vinyl-format` for A/B side organization
- Series pattern configuration for different labels

## Use Cases
- Deep electronic music collections with label focus
- Vinyl rip libraries requiring authentic organization
- DJ collections needing remix accessibility
- Label enthusiasts tracking series completion
- Underground music archives with complex catalog systems

## Priority
High - Essential for serious electronic music collectors and DJs

Successfully implemented comprehensive electronic music organization with all requested features and more\!

### ðŸŽ¯ Features Delivered

issue.title: MusicBrainz integration for comprehensive electronic music metadata

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
## Problem
Electronic music often lacks comprehensive metadata coverage in commercial databases. MusicBrainz provides the most complete open database for electronic music, including underground releases, proper remix credits, and detailed relationship data.

## Solution
Implement MusicBrainz API integration specifically optimized for electronic music that:
- Provides comprehensive metadata for underground and mainstream electronic releases
- Handles complex electronic music relationships (remixers, producers, collaborators)
- Offers accurate genre/tag data from community contributions
- Supports release group relationships for different formats of same release
- Integrates with existing Discogs enrichment for maximum coverage

## MusicBrainz Advantages for Electronic Music
### **Comprehensive Coverage**
- Extensive underground label coverage
- Detailed remix and collaboration credits
- Multiple release formats (12", digital, CD) linked properly
- Community-driven accuracy for niche genres

### **Relationship Data**
- Producer, remixer, engineer, and collaborator credits
- Label and series relationships
- Original vs remix vs edit relationships
- Release group hierarchies (album â†’ singles â†’ remixes)

### **Genre/Tag Accuracy**
- Community-maintained electronic subgenre tags
- Accurate tempo and key information where available
- Mood and style tags specific to electronic music
- Era and movement tagging (Detroit techno, UK garage, etc.)

## Features
- `--musicbrainz-enrich` flag for MusicBrainz metadata lookup
- Multi-source enrichment strategy (MusicBrainz + Discogs fallback)
- Release group analysis for complete discography mapping
- Advanced relationship extraction:
  - Original artist vs remixer distinction
  - Producer and engineer credits
  - Label and sublabel relationships
  - Series and compilation memberships
- Community tag integration for genre accuracy
- Rate-limited API with respectful usage patterns

## Electronic Music Specific Enhancements
### **Remix Chain Analysis**
- Original release â†’ remix releases mapping
- Remixer discography building
- Cross-referencing remix appearances

### **Label Network Mapping**
- Parent label vs sublabel relationships
- Label artist roster tracking
- Catalog number series validation

### **Genre Intelligence**
- Electronic subgenre accuracy (house, techno, drum & bass, etc.)
- Era-specific tagging (acid house, UK garage, minimal techno)
- Regional scene identification (Detroit, Berlin, UK, etc.)

## Integration Strategy
1. **Primary**: MusicBrainz lookup for comprehensive relationship data
2. **Secondary**: Discogs fallback for commercial release information
3. **Tertiary**: Last.fm for additional tag/genre data
4. **Validation**: Cross-reference between sources for accuracy

## Use Cases
- Academic electronic music archives requiring detailed metadata
- DJ collections needing accurate remix and producer credits
- Label discography completion projects
- Electronic music research and analysis
- Comprehensive genre and style organization

## Implementation
- Parallel API queries with intelligent caching
- Confidence scoring across multiple sources
- Conflict resolution between different metadata sources
- Preview mode for metadata changes before application
- Integration with electronic music organization modes

## Priority
Medium-High - Provides the most comprehensive metadata source for serious electronic music collections

comment.body:
# ðŸ”„ MusicBrainz Integration - Complementary to Discogs

## How MusicBrainz Will Enhance Existing Discogs Integration

With Discogs API integration (#19) now complete, MusicBrainz can provide complementary metadata for comprehensive coverage.

### ðŸŽ¯ Integration Architecture Already in Place

The Discogs implementation provides a reusable pattern for MusicBrainz:

**Metadata Enrichment Function** (`ordr.fm.sh:472-533`):
```bash
enrich_metadata_with_discogs() {
    local album_artist="$1"
    local album_title="$2"
    local album_year="$3"
    
    # Search for releases
    local search_results
    search_results=$(discogs_search_releases "$album_artist" "$album_title" "$album_year")
    
    # Calculate confidence score
    local confidence
    confidence=$(calculate_discogs_confidence "$album_artist" "$album_title" "$album_year" "$enhanced_metadata")
    
    echo "$enhanced_metadata"
}
```

### ðŸ”— MusicBrainz Can Follow Same Pattern

```bash
# Proposed parallel function
enrich_metadata_with_musicbrainz() {
    local album_artist="$1"
    local album_title="$2"
    local album_year="$3"
    
    # Use similar search, cache, and confidence scoring
    # MusicBrainz provides MBIDs, ISRCs, and AcoustIDs
}
```

### ðŸ“Š Complementary Data Sources

**Discogs Strengths** (Already Implemented):
- âœ… Catalog numbers for physical releases
- âœ… Vinyl and CD specific information  
- âœ… Label and pressing details
- âœ… Marketplace and collection data
- âœ… DJ and electronic music focus

**MusicBrainz Strengths** (To Implement):
- ðŸŽ¯ MBID (unique identifiers)
- ðŸŽ¯ ISRC codes for digital tracks
- ðŸŽ¯ AcoustID fingerprinting
- ðŸŽ¯ Extensive classical and jazz metadata
- ðŸŽ¯ Recording vs Release distinction

### ðŸ’¡ Proposed Metadata Fusion Strategy

```bash
# Combine both sources with confidence weighting
combine_metadata_sources() {
    local discogs_data="$1"
    local musicbrainz_data="$2"
    
    local discogs_confidence=$(echo "$discogs_data" | jq -r '.confidence')
    local mb_confidence=$(echo "$musicbrainz_data" | jq -r '.confidence')
    
    # Use highest confidence source for each field
    if [[ $(echo "$discogs_confidence > $mb_confidence" | bc -l) -eq 1 ]]; then
        primary_source="discogs"
    else
        primary_source="musicbrainz"
    fi
    
    # Merge unique fields from both sources
    # Catalog numbers from Discogs, ISRCs from MusicBrainz
}
```

### ðŸ—ï¸ Reusable Components from Discogs Implementation

1. **Caching System** (`ordr.fm.sh:198-239`)
   - Can be extended for MusicBrainz responses
   - Same cache key generation logic

2. **Rate Limiting** (`ordr.fm.sh:154-182`)
   - Adapt for MusicBrainz rate limits (1 req/sec)
   - Reuse throttling mechanism

3. **Confidence Scoring** (`ordr.fm.sh:412-469`)
   - Apply same fuzzy matching logic
   - Weight MusicBrainz-specific fields

4. **Configuration Structure** (`ordr.fm.conf:60-94`)
   - Mirror Discogs settings for MusicBrainz
   - Same enable/disable toggles

### ðŸ“‹ Implementation Approach

1. **Duplicate Discogs functions for MusicBrainz**
   - `musicbrainz_api_request()`
   - `musicbrainz_search_releases()`
   - `calculate_musicbrainz_confidence()`

2. **Add MusicBrainz-specific extractors**
   - MBID extraction
   - ISRC code parsing
   - Recording vs Release handling

3. **Implement metadata fusion**
   - Combine both sources intelligently
   - Resolve conflicts based on confidence
   - Log source attribution

4. **Extend configuration**
   - `MUSICBRAINZ_ENABLED`
   - `MUSICBRAINZ_RATE_LIMIT`
   - `METADATA_PRIORITY` (discogs|musicbrainz|highest_confidence)

### ðŸŽµ Electronic Music Benefits

Combined Discogs + MusicBrainz provides:
- **Complete catalog numbers** (physical from Discogs, digital from MusicBrainz)
- **Cross-referenced artist names** (aliases and variations)
- **Verified release dates** (original vs reissue)
- **Comprehensive remix credits** (both databases)
- **Label history** (ownership changes and sublabels)

The foundation is solid - MusicBrainz integration can build directly on the Discogs implementation patterns\!

comment.body:
# ðŸŽ¯ Ready for Implementation - Foundation Complete

## Discogs Integration (#19) Enables This Feature

The completed Discogs API integration provides the essential foundation for advanced electronic music organization:

### âœ… Foundation Already Built

**Catalog Number Extraction** (`ordr.fm.sh:1784-1789`):
```bash
if [[ $DISCOGS_CATALOG_NUMBERS -eq 1 ]]; then
    catalog_number=$(echo "$discogs_metadata" | jq -r '.catalog_number // empty')
    if [[ -n "$catalog_number" ]]; then
        log $LOG_DEBUG "Found catalog number from Discogs: $catalog_number"
    fi
fi
```

**Label Information Available** (`ordr.fm.sh:368-369`):
```bash
local discogs_label=$(echo "$release_json" | jq -r '.labels[0].name // empty' 2>/dev/null)
local discogs_catalog=$(echo "$release_json" | jq -r '.labels[0].catno // empty' 2>/dev/null)
```

**Remix Detection Implemented** (`ordr.fm.sh:374-377`):
```bash
if [[ $DISCOGS_REMIX_ARTISTS -eq 1 ]]; then
    remix_artists=$(echo "$release_json" | jq -r '.tracklist[]? | .title' 2>/dev/null | grep -i "remix\|rmx" | head -5 | tr '\n' ';' || echo "")
fi
```

**Label Series Extraction** (`ordr.fm.sh:380-383`):
```bash
if [[ $DISCOGS_LABEL_SERIES -eq 1 ]]; then
    label_series=$(echo "$release_json" | jq -r '.series[]?.name // empty' 2>/dev/null | head -1)
fi
```

### ðŸš€ Ready to Build Advanced Features

With the Discogs foundation complete, we can now implement:

1. **Label-Based Organization**
   - Use extracted `discogs_label` for directory structure
   - Pattern: `{quality}/{label}/{artist}/{album_year}`

2. **Series-Based Grouping**
   - Use `label_series` for compilation organization
   - Pattern: `{quality}/Compilations/{series}/{album_year}`

3. **Remix Hierarchies**
   - Parse `remix_artists` for specialized organization
   - Pattern: `{quality}/{original_artist}/Remixes/{remixer}/{album}`

4. **Vinyl Side Detection**
   - Parse tracklist for A1, A2, B1, B2 patterns
   - Add side markers to track names

5. **Underground Label Handling**
   - Special patterns for white labels and promos
   - Catalog-number-first organization for unknown artists

### ðŸ“‹ Proposed Implementation Plan

1. **Add organization pattern templates** to configuration
2. **Create label-priority sorting function**
3. **Implement remix detection and path routing**
4. **Add vinyl side parsing from Discogs tracklist**
5. **Create underground/bootleg detection rules**

### ðŸ’¡ Example Enhanced Organization

**Current (with Discogs #19):**
```
Lossless/Bicep/Isles (2021) [NINJA398CD]/
```

**With Advanced Organization (#20):**
```
Lossless/Labels/Ninja Tune/Bicep/Isles (2021) [NINJA398CD]/
Lossless/Series/Fabric Mix Series/Fabric 98 - Maceo Plex (2018)/
Lossless/Remixes/Tale Of Us/Stephan Bodzin - Powers of Ten (Tale Of Us Remix)/
```

The groundwork is complete - ready to implement these advanced electronic music features\!

issue.title: Intelligent metadata enrichment via Discogs API

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
## Problem
Electronic music collections often have incomplete or inconsistent metadata, especially from underground labels, vinyl rips, or rare releases. Manual metadata correction is time-consuming and prone to errors.

## Solution
Implement Discogs API integration for intelligent metadata enrichment that:
- Queries Discogs database for missing/incomplete metadata
- Matches releases using multiple strategies (catalog number, artist+title, barcode)
- Enriches metadata with accurate label, catalog number, year, genre information
- Handles electronic music specifics (remix credits, label series, compilation details)
- Provides confidence scoring for automatic vs manual review

## Features
- `--enrich-metadata` flag to enable Discogs lookup
- `--discogs-token <token>` for API authentication
- Multiple matching strategies with fallback options:
  - Exact catalog number match (highest confidence)
  - Artist + album title + year fuzzy matching
  - Barcode/UPC lookup for commercial releases
- Electronic music specific enhancements:
  - Remix artist extraction and standardization
  - Label series identification (Kompakt Pop Ambient, Warp Records, etc.)
  - Release format detection (12", EP, LP, compilation)
  - Genre/style tagging from Discogs taxonomy
- Confidence thresholds for automatic vs manual review
- Batch processing with rate limiting (API respectful)
- Metadata backup before enrichment

## Electronic Music Specific Benefits
- **Underground Labels**: Often well-documented on Discogs vs other services
- **Vinyl Rips**: Catalog numbers provide exact release identification
- **Remix Credits**: Proper attribution for remixers and collaborators
- **Label History**: Comprehensive label and series information
- **Genre Accuracy**: Electronic subgenre specificity (techno, house, ambient, etc.)

## Use Cases
- Enriching vinyl rip collections with proper metadata
- Standardizing metadata across different sources
- Adding missing catalog numbers for organization
- Correcting artist name variations and remix credits
- Enhancing genre tagging for electronic subgenres

## Implementation
- Rate-limited API calls (respecting Discogs limits)
- Caching to avoid duplicate lookups
- Metadata conflict resolution strategies
- Preview mode to review changes before applying
- Integration with existing --catalog organization mode

## Priority
High - Critical for electronic music collectors with incomplete metadata

# âœ… Discogs API Integration - COMPLETED

## Implementation Summary
Successfully implemented comprehensive Discogs API integration with all planned features operational and production-ready.

## ðŸŽ¯ All Requested Features Implemented

### 1. **Discogs API Authentication and Rate Limiting**
**Evidence from `ordr.fm.sh:266-273`:**
```bash
# Set up authentication
if [[ -n "$DISCOGS_USER_TOKEN" ]]; then
    auth_header="Authorization: Discogs token=${DISCOGS_USER_TOKEN}"
elif [[ -n "$DISCOGS_CONSUMER_KEY" && -n "$DISCOGS_CONSUMER_SECRET" ]]; then
    auth_header="Authorization: Discogs key=${DISCOGS_CONSUMER_KEY}, secret=${DISCOGS_CONSUMER_SECRET}"
else
    log $LOG_WARNING "WARN: No Discogs authentication configured. Using unauthenticated requests (lower rate limit)."
fi
```

**Rate limiting implementation `ordr.fm.sh:154-182`:**
```bash
discogs_rate_limit() {
    local current_time=$(date +%s)
    local last_request_time
    
    # Calculate time since last request
    local time_diff=$((current_time - last_request_time))
    local min_interval=$((60 / DISCOGS_RATE_LIMIT))  # seconds between requests
    
    if [[ $time_diff -lt $min_interval ]]; then
        local sleep_time=$((min_interval - time_diff))
        log $LOG_DEBUG "Rate limiting: sleeping for $sleep_time seconds"
        sleep $sleep_time
    fi
}
```

### 2. **Catalog Number Matching for Electronic Releases**
**Evidence from `ordr.fm.sh:1784-1789`:**
```bash
# Extract catalog number if enabled
if [[ $DISCOGS_CATALOG_NUMBERS -eq 1 ]]; then
    catalog_number=$(echo "$discogs_metadata" | jq -r '.catalog_number // empty')
    if [[ -n "$catalog_number" ]]; then
        log $LOG_DEBUG "Found catalog number from Discogs: $catalog_number"
    fi
fi
```

**Directory naming integration `ordr.fm.sh:1826-1834`:**
```bash
# Include catalog number in directory name if available
local catalog_suffix=""
if [[ -n "$catalog_number" ]]; then
    local sanitized_catalog=$(sanitize_filename "$catalog_number")
    catalog_suffix=" [$sanitized_catalog]"
fi

local new_album_dir_name="${sanitized_album_title}${sanitized_album_year}${catalog_suffix}"
proposed_album_path="${DEST_DIR}/${album_quality}/${sanitized_album_artist}/${new_album_dir_name}"
```

### 3. **Remix Artist Extraction and Label Series Identification**
**Evidence from `ordr.fm.sh:373-383`:**
```bash
# Extract remix artists if enabled
local remix_artists=""
if [[ $DISCOGS_REMIX_ARTISTS -eq 1 ]]; then
    remix_artists=$(echo "$release_json" | jq -r '.tracklist[]? | .title' 2>/dev/null | grep -i "remix\|rmx" | head -5 | tr '\n' ';' || echo "")
fi

# Extract label series information if enabled
local label_series=""
if [[ $DISCOGS_LABEL_SERIES -eq 1 ]]; then
    label_series=$(echo "$release_json" | jq -r '.series[]?.name // empty' 2>/dev/null | head -1)
fi
```

### 4. **Metadata Conflict Resolution and Confidence Scoring**
**Evidence from `ordr.fm.sh:412-469`:**
```bash
calculate_discogs_confidence() {
    local local_artist="$1"
    local local_album="$2"
    local local_year="$3"
    local discogs_metadata="$4"
    
    # Artist matching (weight: 1.0)
    if [[ "$norm_local_artist" == "$norm_discogs_artist" ]]; then
        artist_similarity=1.0
    elif [[ "$norm_local_artist" == *"$norm_discogs_artist"* ]] || [[ "$norm_discogs_artist" == *"$norm_local_artist"* ]]; then
        artist_similarity=0.7
    else
        artist_similarity=0.0
    fi
    
    # Normalize to 0.0-1.0 range
    local final_confidence=$(echo "scale=2; $confidence / $max_score" | bc -l 2>/dev/null || echo "0.00")
    echo "$final_confidence"
}
```

**Threshold enforcement `ordr.fm.sh:1759-1761`:**
```bash
# Use Discogs metadata if confidence is above threshold
if [[ $(echo "$confidence >= $confidence_threshold" | bc -l 2>/dev/null) -eq 1 ]]; then
    log $LOG_INFO "Using Discogs metadata (high confidence: $confidence)"
```

### 5. **Caching System for Performance and API Respect**
**Evidence from `ordr.fm.sh:198-224`:**
```bash
discogs_cache_get() {
    local cache_key="$1"
    local cache_file="$DISCOGS_CACHE_DIR/$cache_key.json"
    
    # Check if cache is expired
    local cache_age_hours=$(( ($(date +%s) - $(stat -c %Y "$cache_file" 2>/dev/null || echo 0)) / 3600 ))
    
    if [[ $cache_age_hours -gt $DISCOGS_CACHE_EXPIRY ]]; then
        log $LOG_DEBUG "Discogs cache expired for key: $cache_key (age: ${cache_age_hours}h)"
        rm -f "$cache_file"
        return 1
    fi
    
    log $LOG_DEBUG "Using cached Discogs response for key: $cache_key"
    cat "$cache_file"
    return 0
}
```

## ðŸ“Š Implementation Statistics

- **Lines of Code Added**: ~800 lines
- **New Functions**: 11 core functions for Discogs integration
- **Configuration Options**: 13 new settings in `ordr.fm.conf`
- **Command-line Arguments**: 7 new CLI options
- **Dependencies Added**: `curl` and `bc`

## ðŸ§ª Testing Results

### Integration Tests (Confirmed)

## ðŸ“ Files Modified/Created

2. **`ordr.fm.conf`** - Configuration with Discogs settings (lines 60-94)
3. **`DISCOGS_INTEGRATION.md`** - Comprehensive documentation

## ðŸŽµ Electronic Music Benefits Achieved

- **Remix Detection**: Identifies remix tracks in releases

- **Enhanced Metadata**: Genre, style, and label information logged

## ðŸ’¡ Usage Examples

```bash

./ordr.fm.sh --discogs --discogs-token "YOUR_TOKEN_HERE"

# With confidence adjustment for electronic music
./ordr.fm.sh --discogs --discogs-confidence 0.6 --profile downloads

# Result: Albums organized as "Artist/Album (Year) [CATALOG123]/"
```

## ðŸš€ Production Ready

The implementation includes:

- âœ… API rate limiting compliance (60/25 requests per minute)

---
title: "ðŸ”‘ P2 MEDIUM: OAuth Production Implementation - Claude Max Integration & Cost Optimization"
labels: "enhancement, P2: Medium, ai, authentication, cost-optimization"
---

### ðŸŽ¯ **Goal: Implement Claude Max OAuth in Production for Cost-Optimized AI Enhancement**

This issue aims to fully deploy and integrate Claude Max OAuth authentication into our production environment. The primary objective is to leverage the fixed-cost Claude Max subscription for AI enhancements, significantly reducing variable API key costs while maintaining high reliability and providing transparent usage monitoring.

### **Current Status**

-   **Claude Max OAuth Client**: The `claude-oauth-client.js` is fully implemented, supporting PKCE OAuth 2.0 authentication and refresh token management.
-   **Intelligent AI Router**: The `intelligent-ai-router.js` is operational, providing multi-tier authentication routing (Browser-first â†’ OAuth â†’ API Key) for cost optimization.
-   **Claude Authentication Manager**: The `claude-auth-manager.js` is implemented, managing the OAuth-first strategy with API key fallback and usage monitoring.
-   **Usage Monitor**: The `usage-monitor.js` is implemented, providing real-time API usage tracking, cost calculation, and budget alerts.

### **Proposed Production Deployment Plan**

We will focus on configuring production credentials, integrating OAuth into the `claude-enhancer.js` workflow, and validating cost savings.

#### 1. **Production Credential Configuration**

-   **Objective**: Securely configure Claude Max OAuth credentials within GitHub Secrets.
-   **Implementation**: Obtain a Claude Max subscription (e.g., Max 5x or Max 20x tier) and register an OAuth application. Populate the following GitHub Secrets:
    -   `CLAUDE_OAUTH_CLIENT_ID`
    -   `CLAUDE_OAUTH_CLIENT_SECRET`
    -   `CLAUDE_OAUTH_REDIRECT_URI` (e.g., `https://your-app.com/oauth/callback`)
    -   `CLAUDE_SUBSCRIPTION_TIER` (e.g., `max_5x` or `max_20x`)

#### 2. **`claude-enhancer.js` Integration**

-   **Objective**: Modify the `claude-enhancer.js` script to utilize the `ClaudeAuthManager` for all Claude AI interactions, ensuring OAuth-first routing.
-   **Implementation**: Update the `CVContentEnhancer` class in `claude-enhancer.js` to initialize and use the `ClaudeAuthManager` for making AI requests. This will replace direct `ClaudeApiClient` calls with calls to `authManager.makeRequest()`.
-   **Authentication Strategy**: Configure the `ClaudeAuthManager` within `claude-enhancer.js` to prioritize OAuth, falling back to API Key only when necessary (e.g., quota exhaustion).

#### 3. **Production Validation & Monitoring**

-   **Objective**: Verify end-to-end OAuth functionality, validate cost savings, and monitor usage in production.
-   **Implementation**: Conduct comprehensive testing of the CV enhancement pipeline with OAuth authentication. Monitor actual Claude AI costs using the `UsageMonitor` and compare against API key-only usage to confirm 50-75% cost reduction.
-   **Fallback Testing**: Simulate OAuth quota exhaustion to ensure the intelligent fallback to API key functions seamlessly.
-   **Dashboard Integration**: Display OAuth utilization, cost savings, and subscription status within the `DevelopmentIntelligenceDashboard` (Issue #242).

### **Technical Implementation Details**

-   **GitHub Actions Workflows**: Ensure `cv-enhancement.yml` and other relevant workflows are updated to pass necessary environment variables to `claude-enhancer.js`.
-   **Error Handling**: Verify robust error handling for OAuth failures and seamless fallback to API key.
-   **Token Management**: Confirm that `claude-auth-manager.js` correctly handles token refreshing and persistence.

### **Acceptance Criteria**

-   [ ] Claude Max subscription is active, and all required GitHub Secrets are populated.
-   [ ] `claude-enhancer.js` successfully uses `ClaudeAuthManager` for Claude AI requests, prioritizing OAuth.
-   [ ] Monthly Claude AI costs are reduced by 50-75% compared to previous API key-only usage.
-   [ ] OAuth authentication is the primary method for AI enhancements (e.g., >80% of requests).
-   [ ] The intelligent fallback to API key functions correctly upon OAuth quota exhaustion or authentication issues.
-   [ ] Real-time usage and cost data from `UsageMonitor` are accurate and accessible.
-   [ ] Authentication reliability remains above 99.5% across all methods.
-   [ ] The `DEVELOPMENT_INTELLIGENCE_DASHBOARD.md` is updated to reflect OAuth integration and cost metrics.

### **Implementation Timeline**

1.  **Week 1: Credential Setup & Basic Integration**: Configure GitHub Secrets and modify `claude-enhancer.js` for basic OAuth usage.
2.  **Week 2: Full Integration & Fallback Testing**: Complete `claude-enhancer.js` integration, including `ClaudeAuthManager`, and test fallback scenarios.
3.  **Week 3: Production Monitoring & Optimization**: Deploy to production, monitor costs, and fine-tune for maximum savings and reliability.

---

**Priority**: P2 Medium - Critical cost optimization infrastructure with immediate ROI potential.
**Estimated Effort**: 105 minutes total (focused implementation and validation).
**Business Value**: High - Significant cost savings, enhanced reliability, and enterprise-grade authentication.

This issue aims to fully integrate the Intelligent AI Router (`intelligent-ai-router.js`) into our CV enhancement pipeline, ensuring seamless authentication switching and comprehensive budget management. The objective is to optimize Claude AI usage costs, enhance reliability, and provide transparent analytics on AI expenditure.

### **Current Status**

-   **Intelligent AI Router**: The `intelligent-ai-router.js` is implemented and operational, providing multi-tier authentication (Browser-first â†’ OAuth â†’ API Key) and intelligent routing logic.
-   **Claude Max OAuth Client**: The `claude-oauth-client.js` is implemented and capable of handling PKCE OAuth 2.0 authentication.
-   **Cost Optimization Framework**: The `cost-optimization-framework.js` is implemented, providing real-time cost tracking, budget alerts, and optimization recommendations.
-   **`claude-enhancer.js`**: This script is the primary consumer of Claude AI services and needs to be updated to leverage the `IntelligentAIRouter`.

### **Proposed Integration Plan**

We will focus on integrating the AI Router into the `claude-enhancer.js` script and establishing a unified budget management system.

#### 1. **CV Enhancement Pipeline Integration**

-   **Objective**: Modify `claude-enhancer.js` to utilize the `IntelligentAIRouter` for all Claude AI interactions, ensuring automatic selection of the most cost-effective authentication method.
-   **Implementation**: Replace direct calls to `ClaudeApiClient` within `claude-enhancer.js` with calls to the `aiRouter.sendMessage()` method. This will involve passing the prompt messages and any relevant options (e.g., `max_tokens`, `temperature`).
-   **Seamless Switching**: Verify that the router transparently switches between browser, OAuth, and API key methods based on availability, cost, and quota, without interrupting the enhancement process.

#### 2. **Unified Budget Management & Analytics**

-   **Objective**: Centralize budget tracking and provide comprehensive cost analytics across all authentication methods.
-   **Implementation**: Leverage the `CostOptimizationFramework` to track total expenditure, method-specific usage, and calculate cost savings. This data will be made available for reporting and dashboard integration.
-   **Budget Alerts**: Configure and integrate budget alert thresholds (e.g., 50%, 75%, 90% of monthly budget) to provide proactive notifications when expenditure approaches limits.
-   **Dashboard Integration**: Display detailed cost analysis, method utilization, and savings within the `DevelopmentIntelligenceDashboard` (Issue #242) or a dedicated cost dashboard.

### **Technical Implementation Details**

-   **`claude-enhancer.js` Modification**: Update the `makeRequest` method within `claude-enhancer.js` to delegate to `this.aiRouter.sendMessage()`.
-   **Data Flow**: Ensure that token usage and cost data from the `IntelligentAIRouter` are properly captured and passed back to the `claude-enhancer.js` for logging and reporting.
-   **Configuration**: Verify that environment variables for `CLAUDE_SESSION_KEY`, `CLAUDE_OAUTH_TOKEN`, and `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` are correctly accessed by the router.

### **Acceptance Criteria**

-   [ ] All Claude AI requests originating from `claude-enhancer.js` are processed through the `IntelligentAIRouter`.
-   [ ] The system automatically selects the most cost-effective authentication method (Browser > OAuth > API Key).
-   [ ] Monthly Claude AI costs are demonstrably reduced by 30-50% compared to previous API Key-only usage.
-   [ ] Real-time cost analytics, including total expenditure, method usage breakdown, and savings, are accurately tracked.
-   [ ] Budget alerts are triggered and logged when predefined thresholds are met.
-   [ ] The `DevelopmentIntelligenceDashboard` (or a dedicated cost dashboard) displays comprehensive cost analysis and optimization insights.
-   [ ] Authentication reliability remains above 99.5% with seamless failover between methods.

### **Implementation Timeline**

1.  **Week 1: Router Integration into Enhancer**: Modify `claude-enhancer.js` to use the `IntelligentAIRouter` and verify basic functionality.
2.  **Week 2: Budget Management & Analytics**: Implement unified budget tracking, integrate budget alerts, and capture detailed cost analytics.
3.  **Week 3: Dashboard & Refinement**: Integrate cost data into the dashboard and fine-tune the routing and alert mechanisms.

---

**Priority**: P2 Medium - Enhances existing cost optimization systems with immediate business value.
**Estimated Effort**: 105 minutes total (focused implementation and validation).
**Business Value**: High - Direct cost savings, improved operational transparency, and enhanced reliability.

issue.body:
---
title: "ðŸ”§ P3 LOW: ES Module Migration - Infrastructure Modernization"
labels: "enhancement, refactor, P3: Low, infrastructure"
---

### ðŸŽ¯ **Goal: Complete ES Module Migration for Enhanced Performance and Maintainability**

This initiative aims to complete the migration of our JavaScript codebase from CommonJS to ES Modules. This modernization will lead to improved performance (e.g., better tree-shaking, faster module loading), enhanced maintainability, and a more consistent, future-proof architecture.

### **Current Migration Status**

Significant progress has already been made:

-   **Critical Components Migrated**: OAuth and GitHub Intelligence modules have successfully been converted to ES Modules.
-   **Remaining Scope**: Approximately 52 files still require ES Module conversion.
-   **System Compatibility**: Existing integrations (LinkedIn, cost router, monitoring) are operational and compatible with the mixed module environment.

### **Proposed Migration Plan**

We will systematically migrate the remaining CommonJS modules to ES Modules, prioritizing core components and then supporting systems.

#### 1. **Core Pipeline Migration (Phase 1)**

**Priority**: High - Essential AI enhancement and data processing modules.

-   **`claude-enhancer.js`**: Primary CV enhancement logic.
-   **`activity-analyzer.js`**: GitHub activity analysis.
-   **`cv-generator.js`**: CV generation engine.
-   **`content-guardian.js`**: Content validation and protection.

#### 2. **Supporting Systems Migration (Phase 2)**

**Priority**: Medium - Dashboards, validators, and utility functions.

-   **Dashboard Generators**: (e.g., `development-intelligence-dashboard.js`, `watch-me-work.js`, `career-intelligence.js`)
-   **Data Validators**: (e.g., `deployment-verifier.js`)
-   **File Processors**: (e.g., `cv-export-system.js`)
-   **Utility Functions**: Shared helper libraries.

#### 3. **Testing & Tools Migration (Phase 3)**

**Priority**: Low - Test suites, CLI tools, and monitoring scripts.

-   **Test Suites**: Update all test files for ES Module compatibility.
-   **CLI Tools**: Convert command-line interface scripts.
-   **Monitoring Scripts**: Migrate any remaining monitoring utilities.

### **Technical Implementation Details**

-   **Conversion Pattern**: Replace `require()` with `import` statements and `module.exports` with `export` declarations.
-   **File Extensions**: Ensure `.js` extensions are used for relative imports.
-   **`package.json`**: Verify and update the `"type": "module"` entry and `exports` field as needed.
-   **Automated Testing**: Leverage existing test suites to ensure no regressions are introduced during migration.

### **Acceptance Criteria**

-   [ ] All JavaScript files in the project are converted to ES Modules.
-   [ ] There are no `require()` statements or `module.exports` in the production codebase.
-   [ ] All existing functionality is preserved and operates correctly.
-   [ ] All automated tests (unit, integration, E2E) pass with the ES Module architecture.
-   [ ] Performance metrics (e.g., module loading times, memory footprint) are maintained or improved.
-   [ ] The `package.json` is correctly configured for ES Modules.
-   [ ] The `tests/README.md` and any other relevant documentation are updated to reflect the completed migration and new module usage patterns.

### **Implementation Strategy**

-   **Batch Conversion**: Migrate modules in small, manageable batches, followed by thorough testing.
-   **Continuous Integration**: Ensure CI/CD pipelines are stable throughout the migration process.
-   **Performance Monitoring**: Continuously monitor performance to detect any regressions.

issue.body:
---
title: "ðŸ”§ P3 LOW: JavaScript Modularization - Code Architecture Refactoring"
labels: "enhancement, refactor, tech-debt, P3: Low"
---

### ðŸŽ¯ **Goal: Modernize JavaScript Architecture for Improved Maintainability and Developer Experience**

This initiative aims to refactor large, monolithic JavaScript files into smaller, more focused modules. This will improve code maintainability, enhance developer experience, and lay the groundwork for future performance optimizations like code splitting and tree shaking.

### **Current Code Architecture Assessment**

Several core JavaScript files in the project are significantly large, leading to increased complexity in navigation, understanding, and maintenance. These files include:

-   **`assets/career-intelligence.js`** (~1800 lines): Handles dashboard analytics and visualization.
-   **`assets/watch-me-work.js`** (~1200 lines): Manages activity monitoring and real-time updates.
-   **`assets/development-intelligence-dashboard.js`** (~2000 lines): The main advanced analytics platform.
-   **`assets/cv-export-system.js`** (~800 lines): Manages PDF generation and export functionality.
-   **`assets/script.js`** (~700 lines): Contains core application functionality.

### **Proposed Modular Architecture Design**

We will break down these large files into logical, single-responsibility modules. The refactoring will follow these phases:

#### 1. **Core Module Extraction (Phase 1)**

Focus on extracting foundational components and managers from the largest files.

-   **From `assets/career-intelligence.js`**: Extract `ChartManager`, `DataLoader`, and `AnalyticsEngine` into separate modules (e.g., `modules/career/chart-manager.js`, `modules/career/data-loader.js`, `modules/career/analytics-engine.js`).
-   **From `assets/watch-me-work.js`**: Extract `ActivityMonitor`, `RealTimeUpdater`, and `GitHubIntegration` into separate modules (e.g., `modules/watch-me-work/activity-monitor.js`, `modules/watch-me-work/real-time-updater.js`, `modules/watch-me-work/github-integration.js`).
-   **From `assets/development-intelligence-dashboard.js`**: Extract `DORACalculator`, `VelocityCalculator`, `QualityCalculator`, and `TrendAnalyzer` into separate modules (e.g., `modules/dev-intelligence/dora-calculator.js`, etc.).

#### 2. **Feature-Specific Modularization (Phase 2)**

Break down remaining large sections within the main files into feature-specific modules.

-   **From `assets/cv-export-system.js`**: Extract `ATSAnalyzer` (if not already external), `PreviewGenerator`, and `DownloadManager`.
-   **From `assets/script.js`**: Extract `NavigationManager`, `ThemeManager`, `DataFetcher`, and `LiveStatsUpdater`.

#### 3. **Shared Utilities & Common Library (Phase 3)**

Identify and consolidate common utility functions and classes into a shared library.

-   **Examples**: `EventManager`, `StorageManager`, `APIClient`, `PerformanceMonitor` (as outlined in the original issue description).

### **Implementation Steps**

1.  **Create New Module Files**: For each identified module, create a new `.js` file in an appropriate subdirectory (e.g., `assets/modules/`).
2.  **Move Code**: Cut the relevant code (classes, functions, constants) from the monolithic file and paste it into the new module file.
3.  **Update Imports/Exports**: Convert `require()` to `import` statements and `module.exports` to `export` declarations in both the new module and the original file.
4.  **Refactor Original File**: The original large file should be refactored to primarily act as an orchestrator, importing and instantiating the new modules.
5.  **Update HTML/Entry Points**: Ensure that the main `index.html` or `script.js` correctly imports the new top-level orchestrator files.
6.  **Testing**: Run existing tests and create new unit tests for the extracted modules to ensure no regressions are introduced.

### **Acceptance Criteria**

-   [ ] The five target files (`career-intelligence.js`, `watch-me-work.js`, `development-intelligence-dashboard.js`, `cv-export-system.js`, `script.js`) are reduced in size by at least 50%.
-   [ ] Each extracted module adheres to the Single Responsibility Principle.
-   [ ] All `require()` statements are replaced with `import` statements, and `module.exports` with `export` declarations.
-   [ ] The application's functionality remains unchanged after modularization.
-   [ ] New unit tests are created for at least 50% of the newly extracted modules.
-   [ ] The `tests/README.md` is updated to reflect the new modular structure and testing approach.

### **Expected Outcomes**

-   **Improved Code Maintainability**: Smaller, focused files are easier to understand and debug.
-   **Enhanced Developer Productivity**: Faster code navigation, easier collaboration, and simplified onboarding for new developers.
-   **Better Performance Potential**: Enables future optimizations like code splitting and tree shaking.
-   **Increased Code Reusability**: Modules can be easily reused across different parts of the application or in future projects.

---

**Priority**: P3 Low - Technical debt reduction for long-term sustainability.
**Estimated Effort**: 135 minutes total (Comprehensive modularization).
**Business Value**: Medium - Improves developer experience and maintainability.

### ðŸŽ¯ **Goal: Proactively Identify Next-Generation Performance Optimization Opportunities**

This issue is a strategic assessment aimed at identifying advanced performance optimization opportunities for the CV system, building upon our current exceptional 100/100 performance score. The objective is to explore cutting-edge techniques and establish a roadmap for future enhancements that will maintain our leadership in web performance.

### **Current Performance Foundation**

Our system currently boasts an exceptional performance foundation:

-   **Performance Score**: 100/100 (Lighthouse).
-   **Content Size**: Highly optimized at 34.9KB (73.5% reduction).
-   **Load Time**: Sub-425ms, providing an excellent user experience.
-   **Optimizations**: Significant CSS (75% reduction) and JavaScript (86% reduction) optimizations are already in place.

### **Strategic Assessment Objectives**

This assessment will focus on identifying 2-3 advanced optimization opportunities with measurable impact, without compromising the current performance excellence. Key areas of investigation include:

1.  **Critical Rendering Path (CRP) Optimization**: Explore further improvements to the critical rendering path, including advanced techniques for resource prioritization and delivery.
2.  **Service Worker Enhancement**: Investigate advanced service worker strategies beyond basic caching, such as predictive pre-fetching, background sync, and more sophisticated offline capabilities.
3.  **Image & Media Optimization**: Assess opportunities for further image compression (e.g., AVIF format), adaptive media delivery, and video optimization (if applicable).
4.  **Code Splitting & Modularization**: Analyze the current JavaScript and CSS bundles for opportunities to implement more granular code splitting and modularization, leading to even smaller initial loads.
5.  **Network Efficiency**: Explore the adoption of newer network protocols (e.g., HTTP/3) and advanced compression algorithms (e.g., Brotli) for improved network efficiency.
6.  **Accessibility Performance**: Evaluate the performance impact of assistive technologies and identify optimizations that enhance the experience for users with disabilities.

### **Technical Analysis Areas**

The assessment will involve a deep dive into the following technical areas:

-   **Bundle Analysis**: Utilize tools like Webpack Bundle Analyzer to identify and optimize bundle size, analyze module dependencies, and detect unused code.
-   **Rendering Performance**: Analyze frame rates, paint times, and animation performance to identify any rendering bottlenecks.
-   **Network Waterfall Analysis**: Examine network requests and responses to identify opportunities for improved loading and delivery.
-   **Runtime Performance**: Profile JavaScript execution and identify long tasks that could impact First Input Delay (FID).

### **Success Criteria**

-   [ ] A comprehensive report detailing 2-3 actionable advanced performance optimization opportunities is generated.
-   [ ] Each identified opportunity includes a clear description, estimated impact on key metrics (e.g., LCP, FID, CLS), and a high-level implementation approach.
-   [ ] The assessment confirms that the current 100/100 performance score can be maintained or further improved with the proposed enhancements.
-   [ ] The report includes recommendations for establishing a continuous performance monitoring dashboard for ongoing optimization.
-   [ ] The `DEVELOPMENT_INTELLIGENCE_DASHBOARD.md` and `tests/README.md` are updated with any relevant findings or new performance metrics to be tracked.

### **Implementation Plan**

1.  **Week 1: Deep Dive Analysis**: Conduct detailed bundle, rendering, and network analysis using specialized tools.
2.  **Week 2: Opportunity Identification**: Research and identify 2-3 high-impact, advanced optimization techniques applicable to the project.
3.  **Week 3: Reporting & Roadmap**: Document findings, propose a high-level implementation roadmap, and update relevant documentation.

---

**Priority**: P3 Low - Strategic assessment for future optimization.
**Estimated Effort**: 105 minutes total (focused analysis and reporting).
**Business Value**: Low - Proactive planning for sustained performance leadership.

### ðŸŽ¯ **Goal: Ensure Long-Term Maintainability and Continuous Improvement of the Deployment Verifier**

This issue focuses on ongoing maintenance, documentation, and strategic enhancements for the `deployment-verifier.js` script. While a critical fix for redirect handling (`curl -L`) has been implemented, continuous refinement is necessary to ensure its accuracy, reliability, and alignment with evolving web standards.

### **Current Status**

-   **Core Functionality**: The `deployment-verifier.js` script is operational and plays a crucial role in validating production deployments.
-   **Critical Fix Implemented**: The issue of missing `-L` flag in `curl` commands, which caused false negatives in SEO, mobile, and security detection, has been resolved.
-   **Impact of Fix**: This fix significantly improved the overall score from 54% to 94%, with SEO, Mobile, and Security categories achieving 100% detection.

### **Maintenance & Enhancement Plan**

We will focus on the following areas to ensure the `DeploymentVerifier` remains a robust and accurate tool:

#### 1. **Advanced Pattern Recognition**

-   **Objective**: Improve the accuracy of detection patterns to handle more sophisticated web development techniques and edge cases.
-   **Implementation**: Refine existing regex patterns and add new ones within `deployment-verifier.js` to detect advanced responsive design, modern security headers, and complex SEO structures.

#### 2. **Performance Metrics & Analysis**

-   **Objective**: Enhance the verifier's ability to measure and report on website performance metrics beyond basic load times.
-   **Implementation**: Integrate more granular performance timing and size measurements. This may involve leveraging browser automation tools (e.g., Puppeteer, Playwright) for more accurate Core Web Vitals data, or integrating with external performance APIs.

#### 3. **Cross-Browser Validation**

-   **Objective**: Extend the verifier's capabilities to perform basic cross-browser compatibility checks.
-   **Implementation**: Explore lightweight methods to validate rendering and functionality across different browser engines (e.g., Chromium, Firefox, WebKit) without introducing significant overhead.

#### 4. **External API Integration**

-   **Objective**: Integrate with external validation services for more comprehensive and authoritative checks.
-   **Implementation**: Research and implement integrations with third-party APIs for specialized validation (e.g., W3C validators, Google Search Console APIs, security scanning services) to augment existing checks.

#### 5. **Documentation & Maintenance Notes**

-   **Objective**: Ensure the verifier's codebase and usage are well-documented for future maintenance and development.
-   **Implementation**: Update inline comments, function descriptions, and the `tests/README.md` to clearly explain the logic, expected patterns, and any known limitations or considerations.

### **Acceptance Criteria**

-   [ ] The `deployment-verifier.js` script is updated with at least two new advanced pattern recognition checks.
-   [ ] The verifier reports at least one new performance metric beyond total load time and content size.
-   [ ] Documentation for the `DeploymentVerifier` (including `tests/README.md`) is updated to reflect all current and new checks, their purpose, and expected patterns.
-   [ ] The verifier continues to achieve a high overall score (94%+) after all enhancements.
-   [ ] No regressions are introduced in existing verification categories.

### **Implementation Plan**

1.  **Week 1: Pattern Recognition & Documentation**: Implement advanced regex patterns and update relevant documentation.
2.  **Week 2: Performance Metrics & Cross-Browser**: Integrate new performance measurements and explore cross-browser checks.
3.  **Week 3: API Integration & Refinement**: Research and implement external API integrations, and perform overall code refinement and testing.

---

**Priority**: P3 Low - Ongoing maintenance and strategic enhancements.
**Estimated Effort**: 105 minutes total (focused implementation and documentation).
**Business Value**: Low - Ensures long-term accuracy and reliability of the verification process.

## Problem Statement
Claude-Code currently operates as a static container infrastructure without actual AI integration. To achieve recursive self-improvement, we need intelligent prompt orchestration that combines memory context, execution history, and strategic planning into optimized API calls.

## Technical Requirements
- Secure Claude API client integration with rate limiting and retry logic
- Intelligent prompt composition engine that synthesizes memory + current context
- Response processing pipeline with structured output validation
- API usage tracking and compliance monitoring for production deployment
- Integration with existing memory system (runtime/claude-memory.json)
- Multi-agent coordination framework with role-based specialization

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Container successfully authenticates and calls Claude API using GitHub Secrets
- [ ] Prompt engine generates contextual prompts from memory + work plans
- [ ] Response parser updates memory structure with learnings and execution results
- [ ] Rate limiting prevents API quota violations with exponential backoff
- [ ] Integration tests validate end-to-end API workflow in CI environment
- [ ] Usage metrics logged for optimization and cost management
- [ ] Multi-agent orchestration for specialized development tasks

## Implementation Approach
1. Add Claude API SDK to Docker container dependencies
2. Implement secure credential management via CLAUDE_API_KEY secret
3. Create prompt composition from NEXT_SESSION_PLAN.md + memory context
4. Add response validation and error handling with structured logging
5. Develop multi-agent coordination system for specialized tasks
6. Implement memory-driven context optimization

## Priority: High
Core dependency for all recursive AI capabilities and intelligent automation.
